text: I think one of the biggest beliefs is that an ounce of naivety will be your biggest secret to success. And I think the word even naivety sometimes gets a bad rap, but naivety is the definition of creativity and innovation and canvas and white space and opportunity. And I definitely went into starting this company with a level of naivety to how regulated it was, to the stigma associated with it, to how hard it would be.
speaker: Laura Modi
context: Lenny asks Laura what she's learned about doing something completely new and different, given that she had never started a D2C business or formulated baby formula before launching Bobbie. Laura explains her philosophy that inexperience can actually be an advantage when entering a new industry. She shares how her lack of deep knowledge about the highly regulated formula industry allowed her to approach problems with fresh thinking rather than being constrained by traditional industry assumptions.
text_ko: 제 생각에는 많은 사람들이 '약간의 순진함'이야말로 성공의 비결이라는 믿음을 가지고 있어요. 순진함이라는 말이 때로는 안 좋게 들리기도 하지만, 사실 순진함은 창의력과 혁신, 빈 캔버스와 여백(white space), 그리고 기회의 본질이에요. 저도 이 회사를 시작할 때 규제가 얼마나 강한지, 관련된 낙인이 어떤지, 일이 얼마나 힘들지에 대해 어느 정도 순진한 상태로 들어갔어요.
text_zh: 我觉得最重要的一个理念就是，保持一点天真反而是成功的最大秘诀。虽然"天真"这个词有时候听起来不太好，但天真其实就是创造力、创新、无限可能和机会的代名词。我当初创办这家公司的时候，确实带着一种天真的心态——不太了解这个行业监管有多严，也没想到会有那么多偏见，更没料到会这么难做。
text_es: Creo que una de las creencias más importantes es que un poquito de ingenuidad va a ser tu mayor secreto para el éxito. Y pienso que la palabra ingenuidad a veces tiene mala fama, pero la ingenuidad es la definición de creatividad e innovación y de espacio en blanco y oportunidad. Y definitivamente empecé esta empresa con cierto nivel de ingenuidad sobre qué tan regulada estaba la industria, sobre el estigma que tenía, sobre qué tan difícil iba a ser.

text: She pulls up her screen, she goes, 'Here's the dilemma. We are depleting inventory far quicker than our ability to replenish. And the customers keep coming.' You sit there and your first reaction is 'This is great. We're growing.' And she's like, 'It's not that great, actually, because here's what's going to happen. We are going to run out of product for the babies that are on Bobbie today.'
speaker: Laura Modi
context: Laura recounts a pivotal moment during the 2022 baby formula shortage crisis when Bobbie's head of growth identified a critical problem. While other formula companies were experiencing supply issues due to recalls, Bobbie was seeing explosive customer growth. However, their growth was outpacing their manufacturing capacity, creating a dangerous situation where they might not be able to serve existing customers who depended on their formula for their babies' nutrition.
text_ko: 그녀가 화면을 띄우고 이렇게 말해요. "문제는 이거예요. 재고(inventory)가 보충(replenish)할 수 있는 속도보다 훨씬 빨리 줄어들고 있어요. 그런데 고객들이 계속 들어와요." 당신은 앉아서 첫 반응이 "좋다, 성장하고 있네"일 거예요. 근데 그녀가 "사실 그렇게 좋은 건 아니에요. 왜냐하면 결국 오늘 Bobbie를 먹고 있는 아기들에게 줄 제품이 다 떨어질 거예요."라고 해요.
text_zh: 她把屏幕调出来，说："问题来了，我们的库存消耗速度远远超过了补货速度，但客户还在源源不断地涌进来。" 你坐在那里，第一反应就是"这不是挺好的嘛，说明我们在增长啊。" 结果她说："其实没那么好，因为接下来会发生什么呢？那些已经在用Bobbie产品的宝宝们就要断粮了。"
text_es: Ella abre su pantalla y dice: "Mira, aquí está el problema. Se nos está acabando el inventario mucho más rápido de lo que podemos reponerlo. Y los clientes no paran de llegar." Te quedas ahí y tu primera reacción es "Esto está genial. Estamos creciendo." Y ella te dice: "Pues no está tan genial, la verdad, porque te voy a decir lo que va a pasar. Se nos va a acabar el producto para los bebés que ya están usando Bobbie."

text: So we named the entire growth team, the slowth team. And I mean, they got creative. At some point we were emailing subscribers to nudge them to cancel because we were looking for a way to ensure that we could keep product, and my God, it was a mind-boggling moment.
speaker: Laura Modi
context: Laura describes how she managed team morale during the formula shortage crisis when Bobbie had to shut down their website to new customers for six months. She explains how they reframed the situation by creating the term 'slowth' (slow growth) to help employees whose jobs had suddenly shifted from driving growth to actively limiting it. The team had to get creative with unconventional tactics, including encouraging some existing subscribers to cancel their subscriptions to preserve inventory.
text_ko: 그래서 우리는 전체 성장 팀을 '슬로스 팀'이라고 이름 지었어요. 정말 창의적이었죠. 어느 순간, 우리는 구독자들에게 이메일을 보내서 취소를 유도하기도 했어요. 제품을 유지할 방법을 찾고 있었거든요. 그 순간은 정말 놀라웠어요.
text_zh: 所以我们把整个增长团队改名叫"慢长团队"。我跟你说，他们真的是脑洞大开。有一段时间我们甚至给订阅用户发邮件，催他们取消订阅，因为我们想找个办法确保产品能继续做下去。我的天，那真是让人摸不着头脑的时刻。
text_es: Así que le pusimos al equipo completo de crecimiento, el equipo de "lentitud". Y te digo, se pusieron creativos. En un momento dado estábamos mandándoles emails a los suscriptores para empujarlos a que cancelaran porque buscábamos una manera de asegurar que pudiéramos mantener el producto, y Dios mío, fue un momento que te vuela la cabeza.

text: I think one of the biggest ones I would say is that you need to get to know people personally as much as you do professionally. And that was maybe something I also maybe took a little bit for granted at Airbnb. We had built a culture where people really personally loved each other. They loved working together.
speaker: Laura Modi
context: Lenny asks Laura about specific tactics for building strong company culture, referencing her earlier comments about culture being crucial to everything you do. Laura explains that one key element is developing personal relationships with team members, not just professional ones. She reflects on how Airbnb had successfully created this type of personal connection among employees, and discusses the challenge of replicating this in a fully remote company environment.
vocabulary_highlights: took a little bit for granted
text_ko: 제가 생각하기에 가장 중요한 것 중 하나는, 업무적으로 아는 만큼 개인적으로도 서로를 알아가야 한다는 점이에요. 그건 에어비앤비에 있을 때 저도 좀 당연하게 여겼던 부분인 것 같아요. 우리는 사람들이 개인적으로 서로를 진심으로 좋아하고 함께 일하는 걸 즐기는 문화를 만들어 왔어요.
text_zh: 我觉得最重要的一点就是，你既要了解同事的工作能力，也要了解他们这个人。这可能也是我在Airbnb时有点想当然的地方吧。我们当时建立的企业文化就是大家私下里都很喜欢彼此，工作起来也特别愉快。
text_es: Creo que una de las cosas más importantes que diría es que necesitas conocer a la gente a nivel personal tanto como a nivel profesional. Y eso fue algo que tal vez di por sentado en Airbnb. Habíamos construido una cultura donde la gente realmente se quería entre sí a nivel personal. Les encantaba trabajar juntos.

text: D2C isn't dead. Just the approach for how people did D2C is a bit dated. We should not be paying for every customer and we should be very careful that people aren't getting hooked on the drug that is paid marketing or performance marketing. And I think that drug, and then obviously as we start to see changes on the way certain performance works, it just becomes more expensive.
speaker: Laura Modi
context: Lenny asks Laura about growing a direct-to-consumer (D2C) company, noting that D2C is considered very difficult with many attempts failing. Laura pushes back against the common narrative that 'D2C is dead,' arguing instead that traditional D2C approaches are outdated. She specifically criticizes the over-reliance on paid marketing and performance marketing, describing it as a 'drug' that companies become addicted to, especially as these channels become more expensive and less effective.
text_ko: D2C는 죽지 않았어요. 다만 사람들이 D2C를 해오던 접근 방식이 좀 구식이에요. 모든 고객마다 비용을 지불하면 안 되고, 유료 마케팅(paid marketing)이나 성과형 마케팅(performance marketing)에 중독되지 않도록 정말 조심해야 해요. 그리고 그 '약'은, 특히 어떤 성과형 채널의 작동 방식이 바뀌기 시작하면 자연스럽게 비용이 더 많이 드는 구조가 돼요.
text_zh: D2C(直接面向消费者)模式并没有死，只是以前那套做D2C的方法有点过时了。我们不应该为每个客户都花钱去获取，而且要特别小心，别让人对付费营销或效果营销(performance marketing)上瘾。我觉得这就像毒品一样，再加上现在效果营销的玩法在变，成本只会越来越高。
text_es: El D2C no está muerto. Lo que pasa es que la manera en que la gente hacía D2C ya está un poco anticuada. No deberíamos estar pagando por cada cliente y tenemos que tener mucho cuidado de que la gente no se vuelva adicta a esa droga que es el marketing pagado o el performance marketing. Y creo que esa droga, y después obviamente cuando empezamos a ver cambios en cómo funciona cierto performance, simplemente se vuelve más caro.

text: I look for people who have the ability to make decisions and move fast and not get worried about the outcome. That is the biggest learning in a startup. The secret is momentum and just keeping momentum. And if we try and perfect everything, you just miss the boat.
speaker: Laura Modi
context: Lenny asks Laura what she looks for when hiring people, given her philosophy of hiring those without deep domain expertise. Laura explains that instead of technical skills, she prioritizes traits that support startup environments. She emphasizes the importance of people who can act quickly without getting paralyzed by uncertainty, noting that maintaining momentum is more critical than achieving perfection in a startup setting.
text_ko: 저는 결정을 잘 내리고 빠르게 움직이면서 결과에 너무 연연하지 않는 사람들을 찾아요. 그건 스타트업(startup)에서 가장 큰 교훈이에요. 비결은 모멘텀(momentum)이고, 그 모멘텀을 계속 유지하는 거예요. 모든 걸 완벽하게 하려고 하면 그냥 기회를 놓쳐버려요.
text_zh: 我找人的时候，主要看他能不能快速决策，说干就干，而且不要老是纠结结果怎么样。这是做创业公司最大的收获。关键就是要保持势头，一直往前冲。如果什么事都想做到完美，机会早就跑了。
text_es: Busco gente que sepa tomar decisiones y moverse rápido sin quedarse preocupándose por lo que pueda pasar. Esa es la lección más grande en una startup. El secreto está en el momentum y mantener ese impulso. Y si nos ponemos a querer perfeccionar todo, simplemente se nos va el tren.

text: Your job is not just to keep people going on momentum. Your job is to make momentum. And sometimes that momentum has to be manufactured. And that has been one of my biggest lessons on just how, as leaders and people starting companies, how do you force yourself? And sometimes when it's early on, you're actually just doing it to yourself, creating manufactured deadlines and launch dates.
speaker: Laura Modi
context: Lenny asks Laura about other lessons she's learned about building a company, particularly around creating urgency and momentum. Laura explains that leaders must actively create momentum rather than just maintain it. She advocates for manufacturing artificial deadlines and launch dates as a way to force progress and prevent teams from getting stuck in endless planning or perfectionism, even when there's no external pressure requiring those specific timelines.
text_ko: 당신의 일은 사람들을 그저 관성으로 움직이게 하는 것만이 아니에요. 당신의 일은 모멘텀(momentum)을 만들어내는 거예요. 그리고 그 모멘텀은 때로는 인위적으로 만들어야 할 때가 있어요. 제가 창업가이자 리더로서 배운 가장 큰 교훈 중 하나가 바로 '어떻게 스스로를 강제로 밀어붙이느냐'였어요. 초반에는 사실 스스로에게 인위적인 마감일(manufactured deadlines)이나 출시일(launch date)을 정해놓고 그렇게 자신을 움직이게 하는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 你的工作不只是让大家保持冲劲往前走，而是要创造这种冲劲。有时候这种动力得人为制造出来。这是我学到的最重要的一课——作为领导者和创业者，你怎么逼自己一把？特别是在早期阶段，其实就是跟自己较劲，人为设定一些截止日期和上线时间。
text_es: Tu trabajo no es solo mantener a la gente con inercia. Tu trabajo es crear esa inercia. Y a veces ese impulso hay que fabricarlo. Y esa ha sido una de mis lecciones más grandes sobre cómo, como líderes y gente que está empezando empresas, ¿cómo te obligas a ti mismo? Y a veces cuando estás empezando, en realidad solo te lo estás haciendo a ti mismo, creando fechas límite artificiales y fechas de lanzamiento.
